Name: Adabado
Description: A sour paste used to marinate fajitas (Mexican skirt steak) before grilling, made with vinegar, chiles, and herbs.

Name: Adobado (adavada)
Description: [Spanish] in Texas, a sour marinade paste made with chiles, herbs and vinegar; in New Mexico and El Paso, a marinade for pork made with red New Mexican chiles, Mexican oregano and garlic.

Name: Adobo
Description: 1. A Philippine national dish of braised pork, chicken, or fish. 2. Also, a seasoned Mexican sauce made with vinegar and chilies like the sauce in which Chipolte peppers usually are sold.

Name: Agave
Description: A Mexican plant with large, fleshy leaves. Fermented agave sap is used to make tequila, pulque, and mescal.

Name: Al Carbon
Description: In Italian and Mexican cooking, foods grilled over charcoal.

Name: Alambre
Description: Spanish or Mexican shish kebab.

Name: Anaheim chiles
Description: New Mexican chiles; very few, if any, Anaheim chiles are grown near Anaheim, California now; mildly hot peppers; slim, ranging between five and eight inches long and sometimes twisted in appearance; not normally stuffed because their flesh is thin; dried and tied in strings (ristras), or ground and blended in commercial chili powder mixtures; may be purchased in cans labeled as mild green chiles.

Name: Antojitos mexicanos
Description: [Spanish] snacks; corn- or tortilla-based Mexican foods, including enchiladas, tacos and tamales.

Name: Asadero Cheese
Description: A white semifirm Mexican cheese made from whole cow's milk. Asadero has a mild flavor and is usually found in loaves that vary from 8 ounces to 11 pounds. Asadero means "fit for roasting," indicating this cheese is very suitable for melting; also known as Chihuahua and Oaxaca.

Name: Asadero
Description: Rubbery white cheese originally made only in the Mexican states of Chihuahua and Michoacan, it is now made in the United States; a cooked cheese made from equal portions of fresh and sour milk; frequently sold braided; it melts in gooey strings; also called Chihuahua, Mennonite or Oaxaca cheese; Monterey Jack or Longhorn Cheddar may be substituted.

Name: Asado
Description: Term used to describe Mexican dishes of broiled or roasted meat.

Name: Bolillos
Description: Mexican hard rolls which are similar to French bread; also a short rolling pin 2 inches in diameter and 8 inches or more long which rolls tortillas to a uniform thickness.

Name: Bollito
Description: A boiling bean native to the Southwest; an ancestor of the pinto bean; takes a bit longer to cook; often used in broth-style side dishes of Mexican cuisine.

Name: Browned flour
Description: Wheat flour browned in an oven or skillet; favored by Mexican and pioneer cooks for gravies and stews.

Name: Bunuelo
Description: A Mexican pastry that is fried than sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar.

Name: Calabacita
Description: [Spanish] squash; zucchini. A variety of summer squash found in Latin American and Mexican cooking.

Name: Capers
Description: Pickled hyssop buds which is used in sauces and as condiments for smoked fish and nicoise salad. Sold packed in vinegar or in salt. Small pickled flower of a shrub though to have originated in the Sahara Desert or in the Orient; Mexican capers are large; Italian capers may be substituted.

Name: Carne adovada
Description: [Spanish] meat cured in red chile sauce; traditional New Mexican dish.

Name: Cazuelas
Description: glazed or unglazed Mexican casserole-style dishes; ideal for long, slow cooking, either in the oven or on top of the stove; can also be used as serving dishes.

Name: Chicharron
Description: Crispy fried pigskin used in Mexican cooking for salads, fillings and snacks.

Name: Chiles de arbol
Description: Treelike; chile de rbol; small, thin, 2 to 3 inch long (including the stems), very hot dried chile; usually ground into a powder for use in chile sauces; go well with tomatoes, tomatillos, citrus, and herbs such as rosemary and oregano; common Mexican names are pico de pajaro (bird's beak) and cola de rata (rat's tail).

Name: Chili rellenos
Description: A Mexican dish consisting of a batter-fried, cheese stuffed, poblano chili pepper.

Name: Chocolate, Mexican
Description: block Mexican chocolate; frequently contains cinnamon, vanilla, clove and ground almonds; Ibarra is one of the best brands.

Name: Chorizo
Description: A spicy pork sausage from all Hispanic countries, ranging in seasoning from mild and sweet to fiercely hot. Hotter versions come from areas of Spain and Portugal. Mexican versions contain a large variety of chiles and have a mealier texture and more complex flavor. Some of them even use fresh herbs giving it a green color. Portugal makes a cousin to this sausage called the linguisa, that is smoked and much hotter. Spicy sausage made with pork, garlic and red chile powder, available both in bulks and in links; Mexican chorizo is sold fresh and is often cooked to add to fillings and egg dishes.

Name: Chupati
Description: Flat bread from northern India, made with wheat and resembling a Mexican tortilla.

Name: Churros
Description: [Spanish] deep-fried cakes named for the shaggy, long-haired Mexican sheep they resemble.

Name: Cilantro
Description: A green herb, similar in appearance to parsley. Also sold dry as seeds, leaves and ground. An essential ingredient to Asian and Mexican dishes. It can be found in Asian as well as Mexican markets and most large supermarkets. Also known as fresh coriander, Mexican parsley and Chinese parsley. It resembles flat-leaf parsley, but the flavor is strong and fresh; the seeds are known as coriander; cilantro is commonly used in salsas and soups; was first introduced to the Mexican Indians by the Spanish.

Name: Cinnamon
Description: Known in spanish as canela; the inner back from shoots of a tree called "Cinnamomum zeylanicum"; used in Mexican dishes that are sweet and savory; available in tightly rolled dry quills (sticks) or ground.

Name: Conchas
Description: Mexican sweet-topped buns; named for the seashell design drawn in the topping.

Name: Empanaditas
Description: Tiny turnovers; traditional New Mexican Christmas food when filled with a Southwestern version of mincemeat.

Name: Epazote
Description: Strong, bitter perennial herb used primarily to flavor beans; also known as Mexican tea, stinkweed, pigweed, wormseed or goosefoot; occasionally mistaken for lamb's lettuce; grows wild in the United States and Mexico; flavor is intense, reminiscent of eucalyptus; used for tea, stews, soups, green pipi ns and moles; cooked with all types of beans to reduce their gaseous qualities.

Name: Ethnic foods (food industry term)
Description: Products that a particular ethnic (racial, national) or cultural group favor, such as Mexican, Chinese or kosher foods.

Name: Flan
Description: This is a term that may be used to describe two different preparations. The first use of this word is describes an open top tart that is filled with pastry cream and topped with fruit. Flan is used in Spanish and Mexican cooking to describe an egg custard that is baked in a large shallow dish, and flavored with caramel. The dish is inverted when served and the excess caramel is used as a sauce for the flan. The flan may be flavored with orange, anise, cinnamon, or liqueur. [Spanish] traditional Mexican and Southwestern baked caramel custard dessert; similar to the French "creme caramel" or "creme brulee."

Name: Frijoles
Description: [Spanish] beans; usually refers to stewed pinto beans; varieties are Anasazi, black turtle, bollito, pinto or red (Mexican strawberry).

Name: Garbanzo beans
Description: Also known as ceci or chickpeas. Very popular legume utilized in Mediterranean and Mexican cuisine.

Name: Garlic, Mexican
Description: Mexican garlic has a dark pink-blue hue to the husk and is sharper than white garlic; usually mashed or roasted for Southwestern cooking.

Name: Guajillo chiles
Description: Also known as chili gauque; fresh guajillo chiles are known as mirasol chiles; medium-hot Mexican orange-red chiles; skinny and about four to six inches long; used in stews, soups, sauces; go well with chicken and pork dishes, blackberry and apple flavors, and grassy herbs such as marjoram and thyme; New Mexico chiles may be substituted.

Name: Huevos Rancheros
Description: A Mexican dish that contains fried eggs on a corn tortilla topped by a green or red chile sauce, salsa, onions and cheese.

Name: Huevos rancheros
Description: [Spanish] ranch-style eggs. A Mexican dish of fried eggs served atop a tortilla and covered with a tomato sauce.

Name: Ibarra chocolate
Description: The traditional Mexican chocolate; contains cinnamon, ground almonds and sugar; the modern version of an Aztec chocolate drink that sometimes contained chiles; ideal for making hot chocolate, but should not be substituted for regular chocolate in most other recipes; there are a few dessert recipes which call for Ibarra chocolate; can be purchased in most grocery stores throughout the Southwest.

Name: Jicama
Description: Nicknamed yam bean and Mexican potato; a low-calorie thick brown-skinned root vegetable with white crunchy flesh that tastes like a cross between a water chestnut and a potato; after the fibrous skin has been pared away, jicama flesh will not discolor; primarily used in salads; when eaten raw, it is usually sprinkled with lime juice and chili powder; the smaller jicama are the most sweet and moist. Its flavor is mild and sweet. It is a fair source for vitamin C and potassium.

Name: Jocoque
Description: [Mexican] sour cream that has equal or less fat content than American sour cream. Also referred to as salted buttermilk, although thicker. Its flavors range from mildly tangy to refreshingly sharp.

Name: Kahlua
Description: dark Mexican coffee liqueur.

Name: Limon
Description: [Spanish] Lemon; in Mexico it usually refers to the small tart Mexican lime.

Name: Manteca
Description: [Spanish] lard; fat; probably the most frequently used ingredient in traditional Mexican cooking; has approximately half the cholesterol of butter; fresh rendered lard is best; it is usually best to substitute vegetable shortening unless fresh lard is available.

Name: Masa Harina
Description: Instant corn flour, dough flour; a product developed by the Quaker Oats Company at the request of the Mexican government; used to make dough for tamales and corn tortillas; uncooked corn kernels that have been ground into flour.

Name: Menudo
Description: [Spanish] tripe and cow's foot soup or stew; fiery Mexican "hangover cure," traditionally eaten on Saturday and Sunday; traditional dish for New Year's Day; normally served with lime wedges, oregano, red pepper flakes and hot tortillas.

Name: Mirasol chiles
Description: Mirasol means looking at the sun; also called chile travieso, or naughty chile; the dried pods are used like dried red New Mexican chiles in corn dishes, meat dishes, sauces and stews; when fresh and green, it can be substituted for the serrano chile mochomos:  cooked or roasted meat, shredded and fried crisp.

Name: Mojo
Description: [Mexican] A spicy, rich sauce consisting of nuts, seeds, spices, chocolate, and peppers.

Name: Molcajete Y Tejolete
Description: The Mexican term for mortar (molcajete) and pestle (tejolete); sometimes made from volcanic rock.

Name: Mole
Description: [Spanish] taken from the Nahuatl word "Molli," meaning concoction; an assortment of thick sauces used in Mexican cooking made of chiles. These sauces are made with one or many chiles, and flavored with cumin, coriander, cinnamon, nuts, seeds, and chocolate. one of the most common ingredients of mole sauce is chocolate; one of the oldest known sauces. Their flavor is rich, smoky, and very complex. Some recipes are made with fresh herbs and have a green color. Chicken, turkey, and pork are then simmered in this sauce.

Name: Mulato chile
Description: A dried chile; in Mexican cooking it refers to the chile mulato, a dark black-brown dried chile famous for its use in Mole Poblano; tastes of licorice, chocolate and dried fruit; used in many dark moles; if unavailable, use anchos or pasillas.

Name: Olla
Description: Common Mexican pot which is tall and tapered inward on the top; it is shaped especially for cooking beans; stockpots and saucepans are good substitutes.

Name: Or gano
Description: Mexican oregano; wild marjoram; also called wild, bastard or dwarf marjoram; used to season many foods, particularly sauces and soups; plants grow wild in the Southwest; best substitute is marjoram or sage.

Name: Panocha
Description: Mexican brown sugar.

Name: Physical inventory (food industry term)
Description: [Mexican] "beak of the rooster"; salsa cruda; very hot, raw salsa with tomatoes, onions, cilantro and serrano chiles; called salsa m xicana in Mexico.

Name: Pickle
Description: Mexican paprika; similar in taste to New Mexico ground red mild chile peppers.

Name: Pilaf
Description: A medium-sized pale pink bean with reddish-brown streaks; available dried; also known as a crabeye bean and a red Mexican bean.

Name: Pilferage (food industry term)
Description: Name taken from pintar (to paint); reddish-brown speckled beans that turn pink when cooked; used in traditional Mexican cookery; when a recipe title says "frijoles," it is most likely referring to pinto beans. Pinto beans make great refried beans; they are also good for beans and rice, chili, or served as a puree.

Name: Queso Fresco Cheese
Description: A fresh Mexican cheese similar to farmer cheese or cottage cheese. This white, slightly salty cheese is available in Latin markets and many supermarkets; also called queso blanco.

Name: Red Beans
Description: Dark red beans similar to red kidney beans, but smaller; popular in chili and as refried beans. They stay firm when cooked and are excellent when accompanying rice. They are available dried in most supermarkets; also known as Mexican Red Beans.

Name: Red beans
Description: Sometimes referred to as "the Mexican strawberry" in the Southwest; brighter in color than the pinto bean and lacks the surface streaks of the slightly smaller pinto bean; similar to and interchangeable with pinto beans. Medium-size, dark red beans akin to kidneys and pintos.

Name: Rompope
Description: Mexican eggnog.

Name: Salpicon
Description: [Spanish] shredded or finely cut; Mexican shredded meat salad; hash. Cooked food cut into tiny pieces, usually as a filling for pastry.

Name: Taco
Description: [Mexican] wad or mouthful; fried, toasted or baked tortilla with filling rolled or folded inside. It has either a soft or crisp fried shell.

Name: Tejano
Description: [Spanish] Texan; often refers to the early Mexican settlers in Texas.

Name: Tepin
Description: [Spanish] a dried chile; chile tepin; wild form of the pequ n, it grows along the Mexican and U.S. border; round, measuring about 1/2 inch across; have a searing, dry heat; used in sauces, salsas and stews; Substitute pequ ns if these are not available.

Name: Tomate verde
Description: Mexican green tomato.

Name: Tortilla
Description: [Latin American] a very thin Mexican bread made of corn or wheat flour. They are served both soft and fried. A round, flat unleavened bread made from a dough of wheat flour or corn flour; the staple of all Latin American cookery.

Name: Tortillas
Description: An unleavened Mexican bread, tortillas are flat and round. They may be made with flour or masa (corn flour).

Name: Totopos, tostaditas
Description: [Spanish] southern Mexican term for tortilla chips.

Name: Vigo Coloring
Description: Common substitute for the yellow color of saffron. Can be found in small envelopes in any Latin American, Mexican, or Cuban market.
